Introduction

If you're like many JavaScript developers, you want to write in TypeScript. It sounds great, but how do you use it in the real world? In this tutorial, we'll build a TypeScript project from scratch, using Node.js, Express, and TypeScript.

Prerequisites

You should be able to follow this tutorial if you have a basic understanding of Node.js and TypeScript. If you're new to TypeScript, get my free guide: TypeScript Essentials: 5 Critical Keys to Using TypeScript Effectively

Outline

  • Install TypeScript
  • Create a new directory for your project and navigate to it in your terminal or command prompt.
  • Initialize a new Node.js project using npm init and answer the prompts.
  • Install the required dependencies for TypeScript by running npm install typescript ts-node @types/node --save-dev in your terminal.
  • Create a tsconfig.json file to configure TypeScript. You can do this manually or by running the tsc --init command in your terminal.
  • Create a new TypeScript file (e.g. app.ts) in your project directory and start writing your code.
  • Update your package.json file to include a script to run your TypeScript code. For example, you can add "start": "ts-node app.ts" under the scripts section.
  • Test your code by running npm start in your terminal. You should see your TypeScript code running in Node.

Install TypeScript

To install TypeScript, you can use npm, the Node.js package manager, by following these steps:

Open your terminal or command prompt.

Run the following command to install TypeScript globally:

npm install -g typescript

This will install the latest stable version of TypeScript on your machine.

Note: If you don't have npm installed, you can download and install Node.js from the official website (https://nodejs.org), which includes npm.

To check if TypeScript is installed correctly, you can run the following command in your terminal:

tsc --version

This should print the version of TypeScript installed on your machine.

Now you're ready to use TypeScript in your Node.js project.
